subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: Trying to define the public interface other than thru Java is a great idea! I ve had the problem of making methods public (or package) for testing and then
messageBody:
Trying to define the public interface other than thru Java is a great
idea!

I've had the problem of making methods public (or package) for testing
and then finding that other people on our team use them. One of the key
reasons is that if you're using a full featured IDE (JBuilder, Eclipse,
...), the IDE will offer your package methods to coders as possible
methods. I think this is one of the problems that people mean when they
talk about 'polluting' an interface.

Comments are an unreliable way of preventing this. Comments get out of
date and ignored too often.

Doesn't changing the methods from public -> private after they've passed
the tests means that you're no longer directly testing the methods on a
regular basis? It does, at least, preserve test driven coding.

I'm mostly relying on my test suite of public methods to confirm the
working of private methods. And not happy about it.

On Fri, 13 Dec 2002 15:16:19 -0000 "Dave Astels <dave@...>"
<dave@...> writes:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Henry Stapp <hstapp@y...> wrote:
> > Hi All,
> >
> > The 'how to test private methods' question
>
> Ah yes... that one. A particularly tricky one it seems.
>
> > Leaving out the backdoor reflection approach for the moment
>
> Yes, please.
>
> > 1) "pollute" the interface by making methods public that should
> be
> > private.
>
> "Pollute" is a stong word. Just because a method is public doesn't
>
> mean it has to be part of the published interface.
>
> My view is that parts of a class that are part of the "public
> interface" and, as such, meant for general use (and that you have
> committed to supporting long term) should be defined in some other
> way that simple the visibility modifier of the method (in this
> case). I would use JavaDoc comments (and fairly detailed ones at
> that) for things that are part of the public interface, and
> (typically) no comments for everything else. Then creating JavaDoc
>
> gives you a document that defines the public interface.
>
> > Some argue that this is the correct thing to do, but generally
> accepted
> > principles of good design seem to require making your public
> interface as
> > minimal as possible.
>
> Yes. So, to go further than the above... and on reflection a better
>
> way, define the "public interface" by making it a Java interface
> that
> your class implements. Then make the interface documented and
> available. Clients must write to the interface, implementation
> details are irrelavant to them, as they should be.
>
> > 2) Only test the public interface, perhaps giving up detailed
> > testing of internal logic.
> [...]
> > Somehow to me (as an admitted TDD newbie), it just seemed better
> to
> > be able to bang on these internal methods directly, rather than
> >relying on the public methods to access them.
>
> f you are practicing TDD, you should not be "giving up detailed
> testing of internal logic."
>
> With TDD you define what you need in terms of external behavior,
> write a test for it, them implement it. Finally you clean up by
> refactoring. So as far as your tests are concerned everything that
>
> the class has to do IS public. When I add a new method in reponse
> to
> a test, it's public. When I refactor and extract methods, I make
> them private. That's the only way I make methods private.
>
> > 3) Make more classes... change the private methods into public
> > methods of new simple classes.
>
> That's a another approach, but I would only do that of the
> functionallity was needed somewhere else. And, I'd most likely also
>
> extract an interface from the new class, and have clients work
> against the interface only.
>
> > 4) Make the methods 'protected'
>
> I only do this in response to the need of a subclass to have access
>
> to somethign that was originally private.. and I try to avoid it as
>
> much as possible.
>
> > have your Test class inherit from your
> > class under test.
>
> Gawk! Ack!
>
> > I'd love to hear the group's thoughts...
>
> Well, I can't speak for the group.. but these are my thoughts.
> (Made
> them myself).
>
> Dave
